analytic.title: AN EXPLANATION OF SUNDRY TEARMES SOMEWHAT obscure, in this translation of Plutarch, in favour of the unlearned Reader; after the order of the Alphabet.

monogr.title: The philosophie, commonlie called, the morals vvritten by the learned philosopher Plutarch of Chæronea. Translated out of Greeke into English, and conferred with the Latine translations and the French, by Philemon Holland of Coventrie, Doctor in Physicke. VVhereunto are annexed the summaries necessary to be read before every treatise
monogr.author: Plutarch

div.head: AN EXPLANATION OF SUNDRY TEARMES SOMEWHAT obscure, in this translation of Plutarch, in favour of the unlearned Reader; after the order of the Alphabet.

list.head: A.
list.label: AUlus,
list.item: A forename among A. the Romans. Abyrtace, A deintie kinde of meat, with the Medes & other Barbarous nations, sharpe & quicke of taste to provoke and please the appetite, composed of Leeks, Garlike, Cresses, Senvie, Pomgranate kirnels, and such like.
list.label: Academie,
list.item: A shadowy place full of groves, a mile distant from Athens, where Plato the Philosopher was borne, and wherein hee taught. Of it, the Academicke Philosophers tooke their name; whose maner was to discourse and dispute of all questions, but to determine and resolve of nothing. And for the great frequence and concourse of scholars to that place, our Universities and great schooles of learning, be named Academies.
list.label: Aediles,
list.item: Certeine magistrates or officers in Rome: who were of two sorts; Plebeij and Curules. Plebeij, of the Commons onely, two in number, more ancient than the other; chosen by the people alone, to second and assist the Tribunes of the Commons, as their right hands. This name they tooke of the charge which they had to mainteine temples and chapels: albeit they registred the Sanctions and Acts of the people, called Plebiscita, and kept the same in their owne custodie; were Clerks of the Market, and looked to weights and measures, &c. yea, and exhibited the games and playes named Plebeij. Curules were likewise twain, elected out of the order and degree of the Patritij: so called of the Yvorie chaire wherein they were allowed to sit, as officers of greater state; and by vertue whereof, in some cases, and at certein times they might exercise civill jurisdiction. It belonged unto these to set forth the solemnities, called Ludi Magni or Romani: overseers they were likewise of the buildings thorowout the city, aswell publike as private, in maner of the Astynomi in Athens: they had regard unto the publike vaults, sinks, conveiances, and conduits of the waters that served the city, as also to the Arcenall, &c. Moreover, they had power to attach the bodies of great persons: and were charged to see unto the provision of corne and victuals. At the first, none but of noble families or Patricians were advanced to this place: but in processe of time, Commoners also atteined thereto. More of them; & how in Iulius Casars time there were elected six Aediles, whereof two were named Cereals; See Alexander at Alexander, lib. 4. cap. 4. Genial. dieth.
list.label: Aegineticke, Mna or Mina,
list.item: Seemeth to be the ancient coine or money of Greece: for they were the first that coined money: and of them came 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Caelius Rhodig.
list.label: Aeolius Modus,
list.item: In Musicke a certeine simple, plaine and mild tune, apt to procure sleepe and bring folke to bed.
list.label: Aequinox,
list.item: That time of the yeere, when the daies and nights be of equall length; which hapneth twice in the yeere, to wit, in March and September.
list.label: Aestivall,
list.item: that is to say, Of the Summer: as the Aestivall Solstice or Tropicke of the Sunne, when he is come neerest unto us, and returneth Southward from us.
list.label: Aloïdae or Aloïadae,
list.item: were Othus and Ephialtes, two giants, so named of Aloëus the giant their supposed father: for of his wife Iphimedia, Neptune begat them. It is said, that every moneth they grew nine fingers.
list.label: Alphabet,
list.item: The order or rew of Greeke letters as they stand; so called of Alpha and Beta, the two formost letters: and it answereth to our A.B.C.
list.label: Alternative,
list.item: By course or turnes, one after another; going and comming, &c.
list.label: Amphictyones,
list.item: Were a certein solemne counsell of State in Greece, who held twice in the yeere a meeting, in the Spring and Autunne, at Thermopyle; being assembled from the 12 flourithing cities of Greece: there to consult of most important affaires.
list.label: Amphitheatre,
list.item: A spacious shew place; in forme round, and made as it were of two Theaters. See Theater.
list.label: Amphora,
list.item: A measure in Rome of liquors only. It seemeth to take that name of the two eares it had, of either side one: it conteined eight Congios, which are somewhat under as many of our wine gallons.
list.label: Amnets,
list.item: Preservatives hung about the necke, or otherwise worne, against witchcraft, poison, eiebiting, sicknesse, or any other evils.
list.label: Anarchie,
list.item: The state of a city or countrey without government.
list.label: Andria,
list.item: A societie of men, meeting together in some publicke hall for to eat and drinke: Instituted first among the Thebans, like to the Phiditia in Lacedaemon.
list.label: Annales,
list.item: Histories, Records, or Chronicles, conteining things done from yere to yeere.
list.label: Anniversarie,
list.item: Comming once enery yeere, at a certeine time: as the Nativity of Christ, and Sturbridge faire, &c.
list.label: Antarcticke,
list.item:
That is to say, Opposit unto the Arcticke. See
〈◊〉 .
list.label: Antidote,
list.item: A medicine, properly taken inwardly against a poison or some pestilent and venimous disease. A counterpoison or preservative.
list.label: Antipathie,
list.item: A repugnance in nature, by reason of contrarie affections; whereby some can not abide the smell of roses, others may not endure the sight of a Cat, &c.
list.label: Antiparistasis,
list.item: A 〈◊〉 or restraint on every side; whereby either colde or heat is made stronger in it selfe by the restraining of the contrary: as the naturall heat of our bodies in Winter, through the coldnesse of the aire compassing it about: likewise, the coldnesse of the middle region of the aire in Summer, by occasion of the heat on both sides cansing thunder and haile, &c.
list.label: Antiphonie,
list.item: A noise of contrarie sounds.
list.label: Antipodes,
list.item: Those people who inhabit under and beneath our Hemisphaere, and go with their feet full against ours.
list.label: Apathte,
list.item: Impassibilitie, or voidnesse of all affections and passions.
list.label: Apaturia,
list.item: A feast solemnized for the space of foure daies at Athens in the honour of Bacchus. So called of Apate, that is to say, Deceit: because Xanthius the Boeotian was in single fight slaine deceitfully by Thimoeles the Athenian. For the tale goeth, that whiles they were in combat, Bacchus appeared behind Xanthius, clad in a goats skinne: and when Thimoeles charged his concurrent for comming into the field with an assistant; as he looked backe, he was killed by Thimoeles abovenamed.
list.label: Apologie,
list.item: A plea for the defence or excuse of any person.
list.label: Apothegme,
list.item: A short sententious speech.
list.label: Apoplexie,
list.item: A disease comming suddenly in maner of a stroke, with an universall astonishment and deprivation of sense and motion, which either causeth death quickely; or else endeth in a dead palsey.
list.label: Archontes,
list.item: Were chiefe magistrates at Athens, at first every tenth yeere; and afterwards yeerely chosen by lot, unto whom the rule of the common-welth in their popular state was committed: of whom the first was named 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, King: the second, Archon, that is to say, Ruler: the third, Polemarchus: and the other six, Thesmothelae.
list.label: Arctick,
list.item: that is to say, Northerly; so called of Arctos in Greeke, which signifieth the Beare, that is to say, those conspicuous seaven starres in the North, named Charlematns waine; neere unto which is that pole or point of the imaginarie axell-tree, about which the heavens turne, which thereupon is named, The pole Arctick: and over against it, underneath our Hemisphaere, is the other pole, called Antarctick, in the South part of the world.
list.label: Aristocratre,
list.item: A forme of Government, or a State wherein the nobles and best men be Rulers.
list.label: To Aromatize,
list.item: that is to say, To season or make pleasant, by putting thereto some sweete and odoriferous spices.
list.label: Astragalote Mastis,
list.item: A scourge or whip, the strings whereof are set and wrought with ankle-bones, called Astragali, thereby to give a more grievous lash.
list.label: Atomi,
list.item: Indivisible bodies like to motes in the Sunne beames; of which Democritus and Epicurus imagined all things to be made.
list.label: Atticke pure,
list.item:
that is to say, The most fine and eloquent: for in Athens they spake the purest Greeke; insomuch as Thucydides called
it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, Greece of Greece, as one would say, the very quintenssence of Greece.
list.label: Averrunct or Averruncani,
list.item: Were gods among the Romans, supposed to put by and chace away evils and calamities: such as Hercules and Apollo among the Greekes, called thereupon Apotropaei.
list.label: Auspices,
list.item: Plutarch seemeth to take for Augures, that is to say, Certeine priests or soothsaiers, who by the inspection and observation of birds did foretell future things.
list.label: Axiomes,
list.item: Were principal propositions in Logicke, of as great authoritie and force as Maximes in law: and it should seeme that those Maximes be derived corruptly from Axiomes.

list.head: B
list.label: BAcchanalta,
list.item:
named also
〈◊〉 , Certein licentious festivall solemnities in the honor of Bacchus, performed at the first by day light, and afterward in the night season, with all maner of filthy wantonnesse: instituted first in Athens, and other cities of Greece euery three yeeres: in Aegypt also: at last they were taken vp in Italy and at Rome.
list.label: Bacchiadae,
list.item: A noble familie in Corinth, who for the space almost of 200. yeeres there ruled.
list.label: Bachyllion,
list.item: A song or daunce, which seemeth to take the name of a famous Tragoedian poet named Bachyllus, who devised and practised it; like as Pyladion, of Pylades, as notable a Comoedian.
list.label: Barbarisme,
list.item: A rude and corrupt maner of speech, full of barbarous and absonant words.
list.label: Basis,
list.item: The flat, piedstall or foote of a Columne, pillar, statue, or such like, whereupon it standeth.
list.label: Baeotarches, or Baeotarchae,
list.item: The soueraigne magistrate or Ruler of the Boeotians.
list.label: Baeotius,
list.item: a kinde of Mesure or Note in Musick used in Baeotia.

list.head: C
list.label: CAius,
list.item: A common forename to many C. families in Rome, and Caia to the woman kinde: as usuall as John and Jone with us, as appeereth by this forme of speech ordinary in mariage; Where thou art Caius, I will be Caia.
list.label: Calends.
list.item: See Kalends.
list.label: Callasitres,
list.item: Hardnesse in maner of brawn, as in the skinne of hands or feet, occasioned by much labour and trauell.
list.label: Cancerous,
list.item: that is to say, Resembling a certeine hard tumor or swelling, occasioned by melancholicke bloud, named a Cancer, for the likenesse it hath to a crab-fish, (named in Latine Cancer) partly, for the swelling veines appearing about it, like unto the feet or cleis of the said fish: and in part, for that it is not easily remooved, no more than the crab if it once settle to a place: & lastly, because the colour is not much unlike. This swelling if it breake out into an ulcer, hardly or unneth admitteth any cure, and by some is called a Wolfe.
list.label: Candyli,
list.item: A kind of dainty meat made with hony and milke.
list.label: Candys,
list.item: an ornament of the Persians, Medians, and other East nations; much like to a Diademe.
list.label: Catamite,
list.item: A boy abused against kinde: a baggage.
list.label: Cataplasme,
list.item: A pultesse or grosse maner of plaster.
list.label: To Cauterize,
list.item: To burne or seare with a red hot iron or other mettall.
list.label: Cenotaph,
list.item: An emptie Tombe or Sepulcher, wherein no corps is interred.
list.label: Censours,
list.item: Magistrates of State in Rome, whose charge was to valew and estimate mens goods, and enroll them accordingly in their seuerall ranges: Also to demise unto certaine farmers, called Publicanes, the publicke profits of the city for a rent, and to put foorth the city works unto them, to be undertaken at a price. Likewise their office it was to oversee mens maners, whereby oftentimes they woulde deprive Senatours of their dignitie: take from Gentlemen their horses of service and rings: displace commanders out of their owne tribe: disable them for giving voices; and make them AErarij.
list.label: Centre,
list.item: The middle pricke of a circle or globe, equally distant from the circumference thereof.
list.label: Centumviri,
list.item: A certeine Court of Judges in Rome, chosen three out of every tribe. And albeit there were 35. tribes, and the whole number by that account amounted to an hundred and five; yet in round reckoning, and by custome, they went under the name of an hundred, and therefore were called Centumviri.
list.label: Cercopes,
list.item: Certaine ridiculous people inhabiting the Iland Pitherusa, having tailes like monkeys, good for nought but to make sport.
list.label: Chalons,
list.item: A small piece of brasse money; the eighth part or (as some say) the sixth, of the Atticke Obolus: somewhat better than halfe a farthing or a cue.
list.label: Chromaticke Musicke,
list.item: Was soft, delicate and effeminate, ful of descant, fained voices and quavering, as some are of opinion.
list.label: Cidaris,
list.item: An ornament of the head, which in Persia, Media, and Armenia, the Kings and High priests wore, with a blew band or ribband about it, beset with white spots.
list.label: Cinaradae,
list.item: A familie descended from Cinaras. Some read Cinyradae, and Cinyras.
list.label: Circumgyration,
list.item: A turning or winding round.
list.label: Cn.
list.item: A forename to some houses in Rome.
list.label: Colian earth,
list.item: So called of Colias a promontory or hill in the territorie of Attica.
list.label: Colleague,
list.item: A fellow or companion in office.
list.label: Colonies,
list.item: Were townes wherein the Romanes placed citizens of their owne to inhabit, either as Free-holders, or tenants & undertakers; endowed with franchises and liberties diversly: Erected first by Romulus.
list.label: Comoedia vetus,
list.item: Licentiously abused all maner of persons, not forbearing to name and traduce upon the Stage even the best men, such as noble Pericles, wise Solon, and just Aristides: nay it spared not the very State it selfe and bodie of the Common-weale; whereupon at length it was condemned and put downe.
list.label: Conctons,
list.item: Orations or speeches made openly before the body of the people, such properly as the Tribunes of the Commons used unto them.
list.label: Congiarium,
list.item: a dole or liberall gift of some Prince or Noble person bestowed upon the people. It tooke the name of that measure Congius, much about our gallon, which was given in oile or wine, by the poll: but afterwards, any other such gift or distribution, whether it were in other victuals, or in money, went under that name.
list.label: Consuls,
list.item: two in number, Soveraigne Magistrates in Rome, succeeding in the place of Kings, with the same authoritie and roiall ensignes: onely they were chosen yeerely.
list.label: Contignate,
list.item: Close set together, so as they touch one another, as houses adjoining.
list.label: Contusions,
list.item: Bruises, dry-beatings, or crushes.
list.label: Convulsions,
list.item: Plucking or shooting paines: Cramps.
list.label: Cordax,
list.item: A lascivious and unseemly kinde of daunce, used in Comoedies at the first, but misliked afterwards and rejected.
list.label: Criticks,
list.item: Grammarians, who tooke upon them to censure and judge Poemes and other works of authors; such as Aristarchus was.
list.label: Criticall daies,
list.item: In Physicke be observed according to the motion of the humour and the Moone; in which the disease sheweth some notable alteration, to life or death, as if the patient had then his dome. In which regard we say, that the seventh day is a king; but the sixth, a tyrant.
list.label: Cube,
list.item: A square figure: as in Geometrie, the Die; having sixe faces foure square and even: in Arithmeticke, a number multiplied in it selfe; as nine arising of thrice three, and sixteene of foure times foure.
list.label: Curvature,
list.item: that is to say, Bending round, as in the felly of a wheele.
list.label: Corollarie,
list.item: An overdeale, or overmeasure, given more than is due or was promised.
list.label: Curule chaire,
list.item: A seat of estate among the Romans made of Ivorie; whereupon certaine Magistrates were called Curules, who were allowed to sit thereon: as also Triumphes were named Curules, when those that triumphed were gloriously beseene in such a chaire, drawen with a chariot, for distinction of Oration, wherein Captaines rode on horsebacke onely.
list.label: Cyath,
list.item: A small measure of liquid things: the twelfth part of Sextarius, which was much about our wine quart. So that a Cyath may go for three good spoonefuls, and answereth in weight to an ounce and halfe, with the better.
list.label: Cynicke Philosophers,
list.item: Such as Antisthenes, Diogenes and their followers were: so named of Cynosarges, a grove or schoole without Athens, where they taught: or rather of their dogged and currish maner of biting; barking at men, in noting their lives over rudely.

list.head: D
list.label: DEcius,
list.item: A forename. For Decius, although D. it were the Gentile name of an house in Rome, yet grew afterwards to be a forename, as Paulus: and likewise forenames at the first, in processe of time, came to name Families.
list.label: D. Decimus,
list.item: A forename to certeine Romans, as namely to Brutus surnamed Albinus, one of the conspiratours that killed Iul. Caesar.
list.label: Decade,
list.item: That which conteineth tenne: as the Decades of Livie, which consist every one of tenne books.
list.label: Democratie,
list.item: A free State, or popular gouernment; wherein every citizen is capable of soveraigne Magistracy.
list.label: Desiccative,
list.item: that is to say, Drying, or having the power to drie.
list.label: Diatessaron,
list.item: A consonance or concord in Musick, called a Fourth, where of there be foure in the Scale which compriseth fifteene strings: it answereth to the proportion, Epitritos; for it consisteth of three and one third part.
list.label: Diapente,
list.item: A consonance or concord in Musicke, called a Five, it answereth to the proportion Hemiolios, or Sesquialtera: for three conteineth two and halfe; three and two make five.
list.label: Diapason,
list.item: a perfect consonance conteining two fourths; or made of Diatesseron and Diapente, As if it consisted of all: an Eight. It answereth to duple proportion, or Diplasion.
list.label: Disdia pason,
list.item: A duple Eight; or quadruple Fourth; which was counted in old time the greatest Systema in the Musicke scale.
list.label: Diastema,
list.item: The intervall in the scale of Musick. Also the rest or Time, of which and of founds or notes consisteth Diatonicke Musicke.
list.label: Diazeugmenon,
list.item: Of disjuncts in Musicke.
list.label: Diaphoretical, or Diphoretical,
list.item: So is called in Physicke Excessive sweat, whereby the spirits be spent, and the body much weakened and made faint, as in the disease Cardiaca.
list.label: Diatonique Musicke,
list.item: Keepeth a meane temperature betweene Chromaticke, and Enharmoniacke: and may go for plaine song, or our Musicke.
list.label: Diatonos,
list.item: A note in Musicke. Diatonos Hypatōn, D, SOLRE. Diatonos Mesōn.
list.label: Dictatour,
list.item: A soveraigne Magistrate above all others in Rome, from whom no appeale was granted, meere absolute and king-like; but that his time of rule was limited within sixe moneths ordinarily: so named, because he onely said the word and it was done; or for that he was Dictus, that is to say, nominated by one of the Consuls, usually in fome time of great danger of the state, and not otherwise elected.
list.label: Diesis,
list.item: The quarter of a note in Musicke; or the least time or accent, G, SOL, RE, UT.
list.label: Dionysius in Corinth,
list.item: An usuall proverbe in Greece, against such as are upon their prosperous estate, so proud and insolent, as they forget themselves and oppresse their inferiors; putting them in minde that they may have a fall as well as Dionysius, who having beene a mighty and absolute Monarch of Sicily, was driven at last to teach a Grammar and Musicke schoole in Corinth.
list.label: Dithyrambs,
list.item: Were songs or hymnes in the honour of Bacchus, who was surnamed Dithyrambus, either because hee was borne twice, and came into this world at two dores; once out of his mother Senerleus wombe, and a second time out of his father Jupiters thigh: or else of Lythirambus, according as Pindarus writeth. For when Jupiter had sowed him within his thigh, at what time as he should come forth againe, he cried foorth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, Undoe the seame, Undoe the seame. The Poets who composed such Hymnes were called Dithyrambicques, whose verses and words were darke and intricate.
list.label: Divination,
list.item: Soothsaying, or foretelling of future things.
list.label: Dolichus,
list.item: A long carriere or race, containing twelve, or (as some say) 24. Stadia.
list.label: Dorian, or Doricke Musick,
list.item: Was grave and sober: so called, for that the Dorians first devised and most used it.
list.label: Drachme or Dram,
list.item: The eight part of an ounce. Also a peece of money valued at seven pence halfe-penie in silver, and in gold much about a french crowne. The Romane denarius was aequivalent unto it.

list.head: E
list.label: ECho,
list.item: A resonance, or resounding of the last part of the voice or words delivered.
list.label: Echo-pan,
list.item: A song, of Echo supposed to be a Nymph not visible, but woonderfully beloved of Pan, the Heardmens god.
list.label: Eclipticke,
list.item: making or occasioning an eclipse.
list.label: Elegi,
list.item: Lamentable and dolefull ditties, composed of unequall verses, as the Hexameter and Pentameter; and such be called Elegiake.
list.label: Elenchs,
list.item: subtile arguments devised to reproove or confute.
list.label: Elotae,
list.item: The common slaves that the Lacedaemonians used, and emploied in base ministeries, as publicke executions, &c.
list.label: Elucidaries,
list.item: Expositions or Declarations of things that be obscure and darke.
list.label: Embrochalion,
list.item: a devise that Physicians have to foment the head or any other part, with some liquor falling from aloft upon it, in maner of raine, whereupon it tooke the name.
list.label: Emphaticall,
list.item: that is to say, Expresse and verie significative.
list.label: Empiricke Physicians,
list.item:
Who without regard either
of the cause in a disease, or the constitution and nature of the patient, goe boldly to worke with those meanes and medicines whereof they had experience in others, fall it out as it would.
list.label: Empusa,
list.item:
A certeine vaine and fantasticall illusion, sent by the divell, or as the Painims say, by Hecate, for to fright infortunate folke. Appeare it doth in divers formes, and seemeth to go with one legge (whereupon it tooke the name, quasi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 :) for one foote or legge it hath of brasse, the other of an asse; and therefore it is named also 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
list.label: Encomiastical,
list.item: Perteining to the praise of a thing or person.
list.label: Endrome,
list.item: A kinde of bickering or conflict.
list.label: Endymatia,
list.item: A kinde of daunce or Musicall Note.
list.label: Enharmonion,
list.item: one of the three generall sorts of Musicke: song of many parts, or a curious concent of sundry tunes.
list.label: Enthymemes,
list.item: Unperfect syllogismes, or short reasonings, when one of the premisses is not expressed, yet so understoode, as the conclusion neverthelesse is inferred.
list.label: Epact,
list.item: The day put to, or set in, to make the leape yeere.
list.label: Ephori,
list.item: Certeine Magistrates or Superintendents for the people in Sparta, in opposition to the kings, and to take downe their regall power: such as were the Tribunes of the Commons at Rome, ordeined for to abridge the Consuls absolute authoritie.
list.label: Epiali,
list.item: Be fevers of the Quotidian kind, that is continuall: they have an unequall distemperature, both of colde and heat at once: but the heat seemeth to be milde and gentle at the first: whereupon they tooke that name. These fevers also, for the same reason be called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
list.label: Epidemial diseases,
list.item: Such as are occasioned by some common cause, and therefore spred, and take hold of all persons indifferently in a tract or city: as the pestilence.
list.label: To Epitomize,
list.item: To relate or pen a thing briefly and by way of an abbreviarie.
list.label: Epitritos,
list.item: The proportion sesquitertion, whereby eight exceedeth sixe, namely by a third part.
list.label: Etymologie,
list.item: the knowledge of the origniall of words, and from whence they be derived.
list.label: Eviration,
list.item: Gelding, or disabling for the act of generation.
list.label: Exharmonians,
list.item: Discords or dissonances in Musicke.
list.label: Exstasie, or Ecstasie,
list.item: A traunce or transportation of the minde, occasioned by rage, admiration, feare, &c.

list.head: F
list.label: FLatulent,
list.item: Windy, or engendring winde: as pease and beanes, be flatulent meat.
list.label: Fomentations,
list.item: in Physicke, be properly devises, for to be applied unto any greeved part: either to comfort and cherish it; or to allay the paine; or else to open the pores of the skinne, and to make way for plasters and ointments to worke their effects the better. Laid to they are by the meanes of bladders, spunges, wollen clothes, or quilts and such like.
list.label: Fungosity,
list.item: A light and holow substance, such as wee may perceive, in spunges, mushromes, fusse bals, elder pith, &c.

list.head: G
list.label: GAlli,
list.item: The furious priests of dame Cybele, the great mother of the gods, honored in Phrygia: It is supposed that they tooke that name of Gallus the river; the water whereof if they dranke liberally, they fell into a furious rage, and cut off their owne genetours.
list.label: Graecostasis,
list.item: A withdrawing gallerie or place in Rome, neere unto the Senate house Curia Hostilia: where Greeks and other forreine Embassadors staide and gave attendance.
list.label: Gymnastical,
list.item: Belonging the publicke places of exercise, where youth was trained up to wrestling and other feates of activitie: the which places were called Gymnasia.
list.label: Gymnick games or plaies,
list.item: performed or practised by those who were naked.
list.label: Gymnopodia, or Gymnopaedia,
list.item: a certaine daunce, that the Lacedaemonian children were trained in, barefoot; untill they proceeded to another more warlike, called Pyrrhica.
list.label: Gymnosophists,
list.item: Philosophers of India, who went naked, and led beside a most austere and precise life.

list.head: H
list.label: HAbite,
list.item:
In our bodies, is either the substantiall constitution thereof; whereby we terme the evill habite (in Greeke) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whenas the bodie misliketh and thriveth not; and the good habite 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (in Greeke) when it prospereth: or els the outward parts; and so we say sweats, pocks, mezels,
and scabs, are driven foorth to the habite of the body by strength of nature.
list.label: Harmonicall Musicke,
list.item: See Enharmonia.
list.label: Hemiolios,
list.item: Proportion sesquialterall: conteining the whole & halfe; as twelve to eight.
list.label: Hemisphaere,
list.item: that is to say, The halfe sphaere or globe, used commonly for that part of the heaven which is in our sight.
list.label: Hexameter,
list.item: A verse consisting of six mesures, called feete.
list.label: Hexatonos,
list.item: Having six tones or six strings.
The Aegyptians sacred Phi losophie, delivered not in characters and letters, but under the forme of living creatures and other things engraven.
list.label: Holocaust,
list.item: A whole burnt sacrifice: whereas ordinarily they burnt upon the altar, onely the inwards of the beast.
list.label: Homonymie,
list.item: the double or manifold signification of a word or sentence, which is the occasion of ambiguity and doubts.
list.label: Horizon,
list.item: That circle that determineth our sight, and divideth the one halfe of the sphaere of heaven above, from that which is under, out of our sight.
list.label: Horoscope,
list.item: the obseruation of the houre and time of ones nativitie, together with the figure of the heavens at that very instant; and that forsooth in the East.
list.label: Hypate, hypaton,
list.item: Principall of principals. A base string in a Musicall instrument: or a note in the skale of Musicke, B, MI.
list.label: Hypate Meson,
list.item: A meane string or note in Musicke: principall of meanes, E, LA, MI.
list.label: Hypate,
list.item: The base string in a lute or other stringed instrument; so called, because it is seated highest & is principall. And yet it may seeme in vocall Musicke, as Lambinas taketh it in Horace, to be the small treble, by that which he writeth of Tigellus, who song Iö Bacche, modò 〈◊〉 Voce, modò haec, resonat chordis quae quatuor ima: where by summa he meaneth the treble, and ima the base. Also Boetius (as Erasmus upon the proverb Dis Diapason, observeth) writeth the cōtrary, namely, that Hypate is the lowest or base; and Nete the highest or treble. Neither doth Plutarch seeme to agree alwaies with himselfe in these termes.
list.label: Hyperbolyaeum,
list.item: A terme in Musick, belonging to their skale, & appropriate to the trebles, that is to say, it signifieth Excellent or exceeding.
list.label: Hyporchema,
list.item: An hymne and dance unto Apollo, performed by children with a noise of pipes before them, in the time of pestilence, and thereupon it was also called Paean.
list.label: Hypotheticall proposuions,
list.item: such as are pronounced with a supposition.

list.head: I
list.label: IAmbus,
list.item: A measure or foote in verse, consisting of two sillables, the former short, the other long: it is put also for the verse made thereof.
list.label: Iambicke verses,
list.item: be they which stand upon such feete. If of foure, they be called Quaternarij: if of six, Senarij: if of eight, Octonarij. Now for that this kinde of foote runneth very quicke, two of them together be reckoned but for one measure: and therefore the said verses, be termed also Dimetri, Trimetri, and Tetrametri, as if they had but two, three, & foure feete or measures.
list.label: Icosaedron,
list.item: A Geometricall solid body, representing twenty sides or faces, distinguished by their severall lines and angles.
list.label: Idaeae,
list.item: The formes of things setled in the divine intelligence or heavenly minde, according to which as paternes, by Platoes doctrine all things were made.
list.label: Idaei Dactyli,
list.item: were certaine servitours unto Cybele, bretheren all, called otherwise Corybantes and Curetes. But whether they were Daemons, fanaticall men, or cousening impostors, it is not agreed upon among writers: neither how many they were, or why so called. See Natalis Comes Mytholog.

* But heere I must not forget to note, that in the Page 257 line 50, instead of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : some read 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, of their owne fingers. Caelius Rhodig. Lect. Antiq. lib. 17. cap. 12.
list.label: Identity,
list.item: that is to say, The samenesse, or being the very same.
list.label: Idus or Ides,
list.item: Eight daies in every moneth, derived of an old word Iduo to divide, for that they commonly fall about the midst of the moneth, namely upon the thirteene or fifteene daies, according to Horace: Idus tibisunt agendae; Quidies mensem veneris marinae, findit Aprilem.
list.label: To Incarnate,
list.item: that is to say, to make flesh, or helpe that the flesh may grow: and so certaine salves or medicines be called incarnatives.
list.label: To Incrassate,
list.item: that is to say, to make thicke and grose.
list.label: Intercular daies,
list.item: that is to say, set or put betweene, as the odde daie in the leape yeare.
list.label: Interstice,
list.item: that is to say, The space or distance betweene.
list.label: Inumbration,
list.item: that is to say, Shadowing.
list.label: Ionicke Musicke,
list.item: Gallant and galliardlike: pleasant or delectable.
list.label: Isonomie,
list.item: An aequability of government under the same lawes, indifferently ministred to al persons: As also an aequality of right which all men doe enjoy in one state: And an aequall distribution unto all persons, not according to Arithmeticall, but Geometricall proportion.
list.label: Isthmus,
list.item: A narrow banke of lande lying betweene two seas, as namely, that of Corinth and Peloponnesus: and by analogie thereto, all such are so called. By a metaphor also, other things that serve as partitions, be so termed.
list.label: Isthmick games,
list.item: Were those which were performed neere Corinth upon the saide Isthmus: instituted as some thinke, by Theseus, to the honour of Melicerta, otherwise named Palaemon and Portamnus.

list.head: K
list.label: KAlends,
list.item: Was among the Romans the first day of the Moneth, or the very day of the new Moone, which commonly did concurre and fall out together: Neomenia in Greeke. But so called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, a Calando, because the 〈◊〉 then to call the people unto the court Calabra, and there to pronounce unto them how many daies there were to the Nones, &c.

list.head: L
list.label: LUcius,
list.item: A forename to divers families L. in Rome.
list.label: To Laconize,
list.item: that is to say, To imitate the Lacedaemonians, either in short and pithy speech, or in hard life.
list.label: Lassitude,
list.item: that is to say, Wearinesse.
list.label: Later all motions,
list.item: that is to say, Moovings to a side; for distinction of those that be circular, mounting upright or descending downward.
list.label: Libations, or Libaments,
list.item: Assaies of sacrifices, or offrings to the gods; especially of liquid things, as wine.
list.label: Lichanos,
list.item: A string of an instrument or note in Musicke: Index: In an instrument: the forefinger string or third: in the GAM-UT, or skale, D, SOL, RE, and C, SOL, RE, UT, according to the addition of Hypatōn or Mesōn.
Any publicke function: but more particularly for the ministerie in the church, about divine service and worship of God.
list.label: Lydius Modus,
list.item: Lydian Musicke, dolefull and lamentable.
list.label: Lyceum, or Lycium,
list.item: A famous place neere to Athens, wherein Aristotle taught Philosophie. His followers, because they conferred and disputed walking in this Lyceum, were called Peripatetici.
list.label: Lyrical poets,
list.item: Such as composed ditties and songs to be sung unto the Lute or such like stringed instruments.

list.head: M
list.label: MArcus,
list.item: M'. Manius, with the note M'. of apostrophus, Forenames of sundry houses in Rome.
list.label: Medimnus,
list.item: A measure conteining sixe Modij Romane; and may goe with us for a bushel and three pecks of London measure, or thereabout.
list.label: Megarian questions,
list.item: that is to say, Such as were propounded and debated among the Philosophers Megarenses: for there was a sect of them, taking name of the place; like as the Cyrenaiks: for Euclides and Stilpo were Megarians.
list.label: Mercenarie,
list.item: that is to say, Hirelings, or such as take wages.
list.label: Mese,
list.item: The middle string or meane: it endeth on Eight, and beginneth the other in the skale of Musicke. In the GAM- UT, A, LA, MI, RE.
list.label: Metamorphosed,
list.item: that is to say, Transmuted and changed.
list.label: Metaphysicks,
list.item: that is to say, Supernaturall. The first and principall part of Philosophy in the intention, although it be last atteined unto, as unto which all other knowledge serveth, and is to be referred. The Philosophers Theologie or Divinity, treating of intelligible and visible things.
list.label: Meteors,
list.item: Be impressions gathered in the aire above; as thunder, lightning, blasing stars, and such like.
list.label: Mimi,
list.item: Were actours upon the stage, representing ridiculously the speech and gesture of others; jesters and vices in a play: Also certeine Poemes or plaies, more lascivious than Comoedies, and fuller of obscoene wantonnesse. The authors of such were called Minographi, as Laberius.
list.label: Mina, or Mna,
list.item: A weight, answering to Libra, that is to say, a pound. Also coine valued at so much.
list.label: Minervall,
list.item: The stipend or wages paid unto a Schoole-master for the institution and teaching of scholars; derived of Minerva, the president of learning and good arts.
list.label: Mixolidian tune,
list.item: that is to say, Lamentable and pitifull: meet for Tragoedies.
list.label: Monarchie,
list.item: The absolute government of a state, by one prince. Roialty.
list.label: Mordicative,
list.item: that is to say, Biting and stinging: as mustard seed, Pelletary of Spaine.
list.label: Muscles,
list.item: The brawny or fleshy parts of the bodie.
list.label: Mythologie,
list.item: A fabulous Narration: or the delivery of matters by way of fables and tales.

list.head: N
list.label: NEmeia,
list.item: Certaine solemne games instituted in the honour of Hercules for killing a lion in the forest Nemea; or as some thinke, in the remembrance of Archemorus a yong babe killed by a serpent.
list.label: Nete,
list.item: The lowest or last string in an instrument, answering to the treble, and opposite to Hypate. Some take it cleane contrary, for the base. See Hypate: and Erasmus upon the Adage, Dis diapason.
list.label: Nete Diezeugmenon,
list.item: A treble string or note of musicke, last of disjuncts. E, LA, MI.
list.label: Nete Hyperbolaean,
list.item: the last of trebles: A, LA Mi, RE.
list.label: Nete Synnemmenon or Syzeugmenon,
list.item: The last of the conjuncts: a string or note in musicke, D, La, SOL.
list.label: Niglary,
list.item: Are thought to be notes or tunes in musicke, powerfull to encourage. See Scholiast in Aristoph.
list.label: Nones,
list.item: Were certaine daies in the moneth: so called, because they began evermore the ninth day before the Ides, honored by the Romans both for the birth day of king Servius, and also for the chasing out of the kings: for otherwise it was not festivall; according as Ovid writeth, Nonarum tutela deo caret.
list.label: Novenary
list.item: number, that is to say, Nine.

list.head: O
list.label: OBolus,
list.item: A certeine weight: halfe a scriptul or scrupul, the sixt part of a drachme or somewhat better in Greece: also a small coine, currant for eight chalci, which in silver is a peny and saithing.
list.label: Octaedra,
list.item: A Geometricall body of eight bases, sides or faces, distinct by their angles.
list.label: Oeconomie,
list.item: House-governement: or the Administration and dispose of houshold affaires.
list.label: Oligarchi,
list.item: A state of governement, wherein a few, and those properly of the welthier sort, rule the common wealth.
list.label: Olympiades,
list.item: were the space of those foure yeeres, according to which the Grecians reckoned the time: as the Romans did by their lustra; and Christians, by the yeere of our lord.
list.label: Olympicke or Olympian
list.item: games, were instituted first by Hercules in the honour of Jupiter Olymptus; or of Pelops, as some thinke: and celebrated with a solemne affluence and concourse from all parts of Greece every foure yeeres complet once, betweene Pisa and Elis, in a plaine called Olympta: where also stood the temple of Jupiter Olympius.
list.label: Oracle,
list.item: An answere or sentence given by the devil, or the supposed gods of the 〈◊〉 : also the place where such answeres were delivered.
list.label: Organe,
list.item: An Instrument. And our body is said to be Organicall, because the soule performeth her operations by the parts thereof as instruments.
list.label: Orthios Nomos,
list.item: In musicke a tune or song exceeding high and incentive; which when Timotheus sung before king Alexander, he was so moved and incited, that presently he leapt foorth and tooke armes.
list.label: Orthographi,
list.item: That part of Grammar which teacheth the feat of writing truely: also, true writing it selfe.
list.label: Ostracisme,
list.item: In Athens A condemnation and confining for ten yeeres space of that person, who was thought to grow greater in wealth, reputation and opinion of vertue or otherwise, than the democratic or free popular estate would well beare, ordained first by Clisthenes: who for his labour was himselfe first condemned. It tooke the name of Ostratos, a shell or little potsherd, wherein his name was written, whom any of the people was in that behalfe offended with; and meant to expell the city. And if the major part of the people noted one in this maner, he was sent away. It differed from banishment, because no person lost by Ostracisme goods or lands: againe the time was limited, and the certaine place set downe, where he should abide. In this sort Aristides the just, valiant Themistocles and other good men were driven out.
list.label: Oxyrynchos,
list.item: A fish, so called, of a long sharpe beake or snout that it hath.

list.head: P
list.label: PAean
list.item: The name of Apollo. An hymne also to Apollo and Diana for to avert plague, warre, or any calamity: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth to strike or to heale, or of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to stay or make to cease.
list.label: Paederastî,
list.item: The loving of yong boies: commonly taken in the ill part, as signifying the abuse of them against kinde.
list.label: Paegnta,
list.item: Pleasant poems or merry ditties for delight.
list.label: Paeon, or Paeon,
list.item: The name of Apollo; and of a metricall foot in verse, of which Paeans are composed: and it is duple, to wit of foure sillables, either the first long, and the other three short; or the first short and the other three long: it is named also Paean: also an epithet of Apollo.
list.label: To Palliat,
list.item: that is to say, To cover or hide: and so such cures be called Palliative, which search not to the roote or cause of the disease, but give a shew onely of a perfect cure; as when a sore is healed up aloft, and festereth underneath. And thus sweet pomanders doe palliat a stinking breath, occasioned by a corrupt stomacke or diseased lungs and such like.
list.label: P. Publius,
list.item: A forename to some Romane families.
list.label: Panathenaea,
list.item: A solemnity held at Athens: wherein the whole city men, women and children were assembled. And such games, dances and plaies as were then exhibited; or what orations were then and there made, they called Panathenaik. Of two sorts these solemnities were: once every yeere; and once every fifth yeere, which were called the greater.
list.label: Pancratium,
list.item: Plutarch taketh for an exercise of activity or mixt game of fist-fight and wrestling. Howbeit other writers will have it to be an exercise of wrestling, wherein one indevoureth with hand and foot, and by all parts of his body to foile his adversary: as also the practise of all the five feats of activity, which is called Pentathlon and Quinquertium: to wit, Or 〈◊〉 the dart. buffetting, wrestling, running leaping and coiting,
list.label: Pancratiast,
list.item: One that is skilfull and professed in the said Pancration.
list.label: Paramese,
list.item: Next the meane or middle string. A note in musicke: B, PA, 〈◊〉 , MI, in space.
list.label: Paranete Hyperbolaean,
list.item: A treble string or note in musicke: the last save one of trebles: G, SOL, RE, UT.
list.label: Panegyricke,
list.item: Feasts, games, faires, marts, pompes, shewes, or any such solemnities, performed or exhibited, before the generall assembly of a whole nation: such as were the Olympicke, Pythicke, Isthmicke, and Nemian games in Greece. Orations likewise to the praise of any person at such an assembly, be called Panegyricall.
list.label: Paradox,
list.item: A strange or admirable opinion held against the common conceit of men: such as the Stoicks mainteined.
list.label: Periode,
list.item: A cercuit or compasse certeinly kept: as we may observe in the course of Sunne and Moone, and in the revolution of times and seasons: in some agues also and other sicknesses, that keepe a just time of their returne, called therefore Periodicall. Also the traine of a full sentence to the end, and the very end it selfe, is named a Periode.
list.label: Paranete 〈◊〉 ,
list.item: A treble string or note in Musicke: the last save one of disjuncts: D, LA, SOL, RE.
list.label:
Paranete Synemmenon or
〈◊〉 :
list.item: C, SOL, FA.
list.label: Parhypate hypatōn,
list.item: that is to say, Subprincipall of principals. A string or note in Musicke: C, FA, UT.
list.label: Parhypate Mesōn,
list.item: that is to say, Subprincipall of meanes: a string or note in Musicke: F, FA, UT.
list.label: Peripateticks,
list.item: A sect of Philosophers, the followers of Aristotle: See Liceum.
list.label: Phiditia,
list.item: Were publicke hals in Lacedaemon, where all sorts of citizens, rich and poore, one with another met to eat and drinke together, at the publicke charges and had aequall parts allowed.
list.label: Philippicks,
list.item: Were invective orations made by Demosthenes the Oratour, against Philip king of Macedony, for the liberty of Greece. And heereupon all invectives may be called Philippicke, as those were of M. Tullius Cicero against Antonie.
list.label: Phrygius Modus,
list.item: Phrygian tune or musicke, otherwise called Barbarian; mooving to devotion, used in sacrifices and religious worship of the gods: for so some interpret Entheon in Lucianus: others take it for incensing and stirring to furie.
list.label: To Pinguifie,
list.item: that is to say, To make fat.
list.label: Plethoricall plight,
list.item:
that is to say, That state of the body, which being full of bloud and other humours, needeth evacuation: whether the said fulnesse be, ad vasa, as the
Physicians say, when the said bloud and humours be otherwise commendable, but offending onely in quality: or, ad vires, when the same be distempered and offensive to nature, and therefore would be ridde away; which state is also called Cacochymie.
list.label: Polemarchus,
list.item: One of the nine Archontes or head magistrates in the popular state of Athens, chosen as the rest yeerely. Who notwithstanding that he reteined the name of Polemarchus, that is to say, a Captaine generall in the field, such as in the Soveraigne government of the kings, were emploied in warres and martiall service under them: yet it appeareth that they had civill jurisdiction, and ministred justice, between citizens & aliens, of whō there were many in Athens; like as the Archon for the time being, was judge for the citizens onely. Assistants he had twaine, named Paredri, who sat in commission with him.
list.label: Poliorceles,
list.item: A surname of Demetrius, a valiant king of Macedonie, and sonne of king Antigonus: which addition was given unto him for beseeging of so many cities.
list.label: Polypragmon,
list.item: A curious busie body, who loveth to meddle in many matters.
list.label: Pores,
list.item: The little holes of the skinne, through which sweat passeth, and fumes breath foorth.
list.label: Positions,
list.item: Such sentences or opinions as are held in disputation.
list.label: Praetour,
list.item: One of the superiour Magistrates of Rome. In the citie he ruled as L. chiefe Justice, and exercised civill jurisdiction: Abroad in the province, he commanded as L. Governour, Deputie, or Lieutenant Generall: In the field, he was L. General, as well as the Consull. At first, the name of Consul, Praetor, and Judge was all one.
list.label: Primices,
list.item: First fruits.
list.label: Problemes,
list.item: that is to say, Questions propounded for to be discussed.
list.label: Procatar cticke causes of sicknesse,
list.item: Be such as are evident and comming from without, which yeeld occasion of disease, but do not mainteine the same: as the heat of the Sunne, causing headach or the ague.
list.label: Prognosticke,
list.item: that is to say, Foreknowing and foreshewing: as the signes in a disease which foresignifie death or recovery.
list.label: Proscription,
list.item: an outlawing of persons in Rome, with confiscation of their goods, and selling the same in portsale: and depriving them of publicke protection.
list.label: Prostambomene,
list.item: A, RE, a terme in Musicke, signifying (a String or Note) taken in or to: for otherwise of two Heptachords, there would not arise 15. to admit a place in the middle for Mese, that is to say, the Meane, to take part of two Eights, or two Diapasons.
list.label: Prosodia,
list.item: A certeine hymne or tune thereto, in maner of supplication to the gods, and namely to Apollo and Diana, at what time as a sacrifice was to be brought and presented before the altar.
list.label: Proteleia,
list.item: The sacrifice before mariage: as also the gifts that ceremoniously went before.
list.label: Prytaneum,
list.item: A stately place within the castell of Athens, wherein was a court held for judgement in certeine causes: where also they who had done the Common-wealth singular service, were allowed their diet at the cities charges, which was accounted the greatest honour that could be.
list.label: Parhypate Hypaton,
list.item: A base string or note in musicke, Subprincipall of principals: C, FA, UT,
list.label: Parhypate Meson,
list.item: Subprincipall of meanes, a meane string or note, F, FA, UT,
list.label: Pyladion,
list.item: In musicke a kinde of note bearing the name of Pylades, a Poet comicall and skilfull master in musicke.
list.label: Pyramidal,
list.item: Formed like unto the Pyramis, which is a geometricall body, solid, broad beneath, and rising up one all sides which be flat and plaine, unto a sharpe point like a steeple. It taketh the name of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, Fire, which naturally hath that figure.
list.label: Pythia,
list.item: or Phoebas, The priestresse or prophetisse, who pronounced the answeres at the oracle of Apollo Pythius at Delphos: who tooke that name of Python there slaine by him and lying putrified: or of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, To aske and demand; for the resort of people thither to be resolved by him of their doubts.
list.label: Pythick,
list.item: or Pythian games, were celebrated to the honour of Apollo Pythius, neere the city Delphos, with greate solemnity: instituted first by Diomedes and yeerely renewed.

list.head: Q
list.label: QUintus,
list.item: A fore name to divers Romanes. Q.
list.label: Quaternary,
list.item:
the number of Foure: called likewise 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so highly celebrated
by the Pythagoreans, comprising in it the proportion Epitritos, whereof ariseth the musicall harmonie
〈1 line〉 . Diatessaron; for it containeth three and the third part of three: also Diplasion, because it comprehendeth two duple, whence ariseth the musicke diapason: and Disdiapason, being dubled, which is an Eight & the perfect harmony, according to the proverbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 also in that, it containeth all numbers within it; for, one, two, three and foure arise to Ten, beyond which we cannot ascend but by repetition of former numbers.
list.label: Quaestors,
list.item: inferior officers in Rome in maner of Treasurers: whose charge was to receive and lay out the cities mony and revenewes of state: of which sort, there were Urbani, for the city it selfe: Provinciales, for the provinces: and Castrenses, for the campe and their warres.
list.label: Quinquertium,
list.item: named in Greeke, Pentathlon. Five exercises or feats of activity among the greeks practised at their solemne games: namely Some put in stead hereof 〈◊〉 . launcing the dart, throwing the coit, running a race, wrestling and leaping. See Pancratium.

list.head: R
list.label: RAdicall moisture:
list.item: Is the substantiall humidity in living bodies; which is so united with naturall heat, that the one maintaineth the other, and both preserve life.
list.label: To Rarifie,
list.item: that is to say, To make more subtile, light and thin.
list.label: Rectdivation,
list.item: Is a relapse or falling backe into a sicknesse, which was in the way of recovery, and commonly is more dangerous than the former: Recidiva pejor radice.
list.label: Regents,
list.item: Professours in the liberall sciences and in Philosophi: a tearme usuall in the Universities.
list.label: Reverberation,
list.item: that is to say, A smiting or driving backe.
list.label: Rhapsodie,
list.item: A 〈◊〉 together or conjoining of those Poems and verses especially heroicke or hexametre, which before were loose and scattered: such as were those of Homer, when they were reduced into one entier body of Ilias and Odyssca. Those Poets also, who recite or pronounce such verses, were tearmed Rhapsodi.
list.label: Rivals and Corrivals,
list.item: Counter-suiters: or those who make love together, unto one and the same woman.
list.label: To Ruminate,
list.item: that is to say, To ponder and consider, or revolve a thing in the minde: a borrowed speech from beasts that chew the cudde.

list.head: S
list.label: SAtyri,
list.item: Woodwoses, or monstrous creatures with tailes, yet resembling in some sort, partly men & women, & in part goats; given much to venery and lasciviousnesse, whereupon they had that name: also to scurrill, frumping and jibing, for which they were also called Sileni, especially when they grew aged; supposed by the rurall heardmen to be the fairies or gods (I would not else) of the woods.
list.label: Satyrae or Satyrs
list.item: were certaine Poems received in place of Comoedia vetus, detesting and reprooving the misdemeanours of people and their vices: at first by way of myrth and jest, not sharpely and after a biting maner, to the shame, disgrace or hurt of any person; such were they that Horace composed; howbeit they grew afterward to more diracity and licentiousnesse, noting in broad tearmes without respect all leaudnesse, and sparing no degree; as those were of Juvenales and Persius penning. Latine poets onely, handled this argument, both in the one sort and the other.
list.label: Scammonie,
list.item: A medicinable plant, and the juice thereof issuing out of the roote when it is wounded or cut: it purgeth yellow choler strongly. The same juice or liquor being concrete or thickned and withall corrected is called Dacrydium; as one would say, the teares destilling from the roote: and is the same which the unlearned Apothecaries call Diagridium; as if forsooth it were some compound like their Diaphaenicon.
list.label: Scelet,
list.item: The dead body of a man artificially dried or tanned, for to be kept and seene a long time. It is taken also for a dead carcasse of man or woman, represented with the bones onely, and ligaments.
list.label: Scepticke philosophers,
list.item: Who descended from Pyrrho; so called, for that they would consider of all matters in question, but determine of none: and in this respect they were more precise than the Academicks.
list.label: Scolia,
list.item: Were certeine songs and carols sung at feasts.
list.label: Scrutinie,
list.item: A search, and properly a perusing of suffrages or voices, at elections or judiciall courts, for the triallor passing of any cause.
list.label: Secundine,
list.item:
The skinne that enwrappeth the childe or yoong thing in the wombe: in
women the after-birth or later-birth; in beasts the heame.
list.label: Senarie,
list.item: The number of sixe, also a kinde of verse. See Iambus.
list.label: Septimane,
list.item:
A weeke or seven-night. Also what soever falleth out upon the seventh daie, moneth, yeere, &c. as Septimanae foeturae, in Arnobius, for children borne at the seventh moneth after conception; and Septimanae 〈◊〉 , Agues returning with their fits every seventh day.
Serg. Sergius
Forenames to certeine families in Rome.
Serv. Servius
Sex. Sextus.
list.label: Sesquialteral,
list.item: A proportion, by which is ment that which conteineth the whole and halfe againe, as 6. to 4. 12. to 8. It is also named Hemiolios.
list.label: Sesqui-tertian,
list.item:
A proportion, whereby is understood as much as comprehendeth the whole, and one third part, as 12. to 9. and the same is called
〈◊〉 .
list.label: Sesqui-octave,
list.item: That which compriseth the whole and one 8 part; as 9 to 8, 18 to 16: in Greeke Eptogdoos, or Epogdoos.
list.label: Soloecisme,
list.item:
Incongruity of speech, or defect in the purity thereof. It arose of those who being Athenians borne, and dwelling in Soli, a city in
〈◊〉 , spake not pure Attick, but mixt with the Solians language.
list.label: Solstice,
list.item: The Sunne-steed, which is twice in the yeere, in Iune & December, when the Sunne seemeth to stand for a while, at the very point of the Tropicks, either going from us, or comming toward us; as if hee returned from the end of his race, North and South.
list.label: Sp. Spurius,
list.item: A forename to some Romanes.
list.label: Spasmes,
list.item: that is to say, Crampes, or painfull pluckings of the muskles and sinewes. See Convulsions And Spasmaticke, full of such or given thereto.
list.label: Sphaeres,
list.item: The circles or globs, of the seven planets: as also the compasse of the heaven above all.
list.label: Spissitude,
list.item: Thicknesse or dimnesse.
list.label: Spondaeus,
list.item: An hymne sung at sacrifices and libations. Also a metricall foot in verse, consisting of two long syllables: whereof principally such hymnes or songs were composed.
list.label: Stadium,
list.item: A race or space of ground, conteining 625. foote, whereof eight make a mile, consisting of a thousand paces, which are five thousand foot, reckoning five foot for a pace; for so much commonly a man taketh at once in his pace, that is to say, in his stepping forward, and remooving one foot before another.
list.label: Stoicks,
list.item: Certeine Philosophers, whose first master was Zeno, who taught in a certeine spatious gallery at Athens, called Poecile, for the varietie of pictures wherewith Polignotus the excellent painter 〈◊〉 it: And for that a gallery in Greeke is called Stoa, therefore those Philosophers who taught and disputed therein, tooke that name of Stoicks.
list.label: Strophes,
list.item: that is to say, Conversions or turnings. In Comoedies and tragoedies, when the Chorus first speaketh unto the actours; and then turneth to the spectators, and pronounceth certeine Jambicks. In the rehearsing of Lyricall verses, when the Poet one while turneth to the right hand, and another while to the left, and so reciteth certeine verses: which thereupon be called Strophae, and Antistrophae.
list.label: Stypticke,
list.item:
being such things, as by a certeine harsh taste, doe shew that they be astringent: as the fruit called 〈◊〉 , and Alum especially, which thereupon is 〈◊〉
Stypteria. And Stypticitie is such a qualitie.
list.label: Subitarie,
list.item: that is to say, Of a sudden, without premeditation.
list.label: Subterranean,
list.item: that is to say, Under the earth.
list.label: Superficies,
list.item: The upper face or outside of any thing. In Geometrie it is that, which is made of lines set together, like as a line of prickes united.
list.label: Superfoetation,
list.item: Conception upon conception.
list.label: Suppuration,
list.item: A gathering to matter or attir: as in biles, impostumes, inflammations and such like.
list.label: Sycophants,
list.item: Tale-bearers, false promoters, or slanderous informers, and such as upon small occasions brought men into trouble. The name arose upon this occasion, that whereas in Athens there was an act, That none should transport figges out of the territory Attica; such as gave information of those that contrarie to this law conveied figges into other parts, were tearmed Sycophants: for that Sycon in Greeke, is a figge.
list.label: Syllogismes,
list.item: Be certeine formes of arguing: when upon two propositions graunted, which are called Premisses, there is inferred a third, namely a Conclusion.
list.label: To Symbolize,
list.item:
that is, By certeine outward
signes, to signifie some hidden things: Thus an eie symbolizeth vigilancy.
list.label: Sympathie,
list.item: that is to say, A fellow feeling, as is betweene the head and stomacke in our bodies: also the agreement and naturall amitie in divers senslesse things, as between iron and the load-stone.
list.label: Symphonie,
list.item: Concent and harmony, properly in vocall Musicke.
list.label: Symposiarch,
list.item: The master of a feast. The Romanes called him Rex, that is to saie, a king.
list.label: Symptomes,
list.item: Be accidents accompanying sicknesse; as headach, the ague: stitch, shortnesse of winde, spitting blood, cough and ague; the plurisie.
list.label: Synemmenon, or Synezeugmenon,
list.item: A tearme of art in musicke, signifying strings or notes conjunct.
list.label: Syntaxis,
list.item: The construction and coherence of words and parts of speech by concord and regiment.

list.head: T
list.label: TItus,
list.item: A forename to many houses of T. the Romans.
list.label: Talent
list.item: Atticke (as well ponderall which was weighed, as numerall or nummarie, counted in mony) was of two sortes: The lesse, of sixty pound Attick, and every one of them consisted of one hnndred Drachmae. If mina then, be three pound two shillings six pence starling in silver; this talent amounteth to one hundred eighty seven pound ten shillings of our english mony. The greater, or simply the great talent, is eighty minae and hath the proportion Epitritos, or sesquitertian to the lesse: so that it commeth to two hundred and fifty pound starling.
list.label: Tautologies,
list.item: Vaine repetitions of the same things oftentimes.
list.label: Ternarie,
list.item: The number of three.
list.label: Terpandrios,
list.item: A severall tune in musicke, or a song that Terpander devised.
list.label: Tetrachord,
list.item: An instrument in old time of foure strings: but now, it is taken for every fourth in the scale of Musicke or GAM, UT. whereof there be foure in fifteene strings: reckoning Mese, to end one octave and begin another.
list.label: Tetrarch,
list.item: A potentate or ruler over the fourth part of a country.
list.label: Theatre,
list.item: A shew place built with seates in maner of an halfe circle, for to behold games, plaies and pastimes; which if both ends meet round, is called an Amphitheatre.
list.label: Theorems,
list.item: Principles or rules in any science.
list.label: Theriacal Trochisks,
list.item: Trosches made of vipers flesh, to enter into the composition Theriaca, that is to say, Triacle.
list.label: Thesmothelae,
list.item: Were six of the nine Archontes or chiefe rulers in Athens during their free popular estate. They had civill jurisdiction and sat as judges in certeine causes.
list.label: Thesmothesium,
list.item: seemeth to be the court or commission of the said Thesmothelae.
list.label: Topicks,
list.item: That part of logicke which treateth of the invention of arguments, which are called Topi, as if they were places, out of which a man might redily have sufficient reasons to argue and dispute with Pro & contra.
list.label: Tribunes of the Commons,
list.item: Certeine officers or magistrates at Rome, as provosts and protectours of the cominaltie to restraine and keepe downe the excessive power of the consuls and nobility. Chosen they were and confirmed by the generall oth of the people, whereby they were Sacrosancti, that is to say, Inviolable, & no violence might be done to their persons. A negative voice they had and power of inhibition called Intercessio; whereby they might crosse and stop all proceedings of the Senate or any superiour magistrate (save only the Dictator) even of the very consuls, whom in some case they might command. They resembled much the Ephory in Sparta.
list.label: Trite Diezeugmenon,
list.item: The third of disjuncts a string or note in the scale of musicke C, SOL, FA, UT.
list.label: Trite Hyperbolaean,
list.item: A treble string; the third of Exceeding or treble; F, FA, UT.
list.label: Trite Synnemmenon,
list.item: or Syzeugmenon, The third of the Disjuncts, a string or note in musicke, B, FA, B, MI in rule.
list.label: Trivtall,
list.item: Common and ordinary as is the high way, stale and of no account.
list.label: Trochaeans,
list.item: A metricall foot in verse, consisting of two sillables; the former long, and the other short.
list.label: Tropaees or Trophaees,
list.item: Were monuments in memoriall of victory, erected in marble, brasse, or in default thereof with heaps of stone or piles of wood, in the very place where any Generall had vanquished his enimies and put them to flight; whereupon they tooke that name: for that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in greeke signifieth, Turning back and flight.
list.label: Tropes,
list.item:
In speech the using of wordes otherwise than in their primitive and naturall
signification; which many times giveth a grace to the sentence.
list.label: Tutelar,
list.item: Protectours and defenders. So were the gods or goddesses among the Painims called, whom they beleeved to have a speciall charge of any city or country.
list.label: A Type,
list.item: that is to say, A figure under which is signified some other thing.

list.head: V
list.label: VEstall virgins,
list.item: were certeine Nunnes or Votaries, instituted first by Numa Pompilius king of Rome, in the honour of Vesta the goddesse: whose charge was to keepe the sacred fire that it went not foorth. Chosen they were betweene the yeeres of six and tenne of their age: and were enjoined virginitie for thirtie yeeres: after which time it was lawfull for them to be married: But if in the meane while they committed fornication, buried they were quicke.
list.label: Vnction,
list.item: that is to say, Anointing.
